animals.Alpaca: A domesticated species of South American camelid, similar to a llama, valued for its soft wool.
animals.Anemonefish: A type of small marine fish that lives symbiotically with sea anemones, often brightly colored.
animals.Anteater: A mammal known for its elongated snout and tongue, specialized for feeding on ants and termites.
animals.Antelope: A group of swift, hoofed mammals found primarily in Africa and Asia, known for their slender build and horns.
animals.Badger: A burrowing mammal with a stout body and short legs, known for its digging abilities and striped face.
animals.Bat: A flying mammal with membranous wings, capable of echolocation for navigation and hunting.
animals.Bear: A large, strong mammal with thick fur, belonging to the family Ursidae, found in diverse habitats.
animals.Bison: A large, hump-backed mammal of the bovine family, native to North America and parts of Europe.
animals.Bonobo: A great ape closely related to the chimpanzee, known for its social and peaceful behavior.
animals.Butterfly: An insect with large, often brightly colored wings, undergoing complete metamorphosis from larva to adult.
animals.Cat: A small domesticated carnivorous mammal, known for its agility, sharp claws, and playful behavior.
animals.Cheetah: The fastest land animal, a large feline known for its spotted coat and incredible speed.
animals.Chicken: A domesticated bird raised for meat and eggs, known for its clucking and pecking behavior.
animals.Chihuahua: A small breed of dog originating from Mexico, known for its tiny size and big personality.
animals.Chimpanzee: A great ape native to Africa, known for its intelligence and genetic similarity to humans.
animals.Chinchilla: A small rodent with soft, dense fur, native to South America, often kept as a pet.
animals.Coati: A member of the raccoon family with a long, flexible snout and ringed tail, found in the Americas.
animals.Cow: A domesticated bovine raised for milk, meat, and as draft animals, widely farmed worldwide.
animals.Crocodile: A large, carnivorous reptile with a long snout and powerful tail, found in tropical regions.
animals.Dog: A domesticated mammal known for its loyalty and companionship, with many breeds of varying size and temperament.
animals.Dolphin: An intelligent marine mammal with a streamlined body, known for its playful behavior and communication skills.
animals.Elephant: The largest land animal, known for its long trunk, tusks, and strong social bonds.
animals.Emu: A large, flightless bird native to Australia, similar to an ostrich, with long legs for running.
animals.Ferret: A small domesticated mammal, related to weasels, often kept as a pet for its playful nature.
animals.Fish: Aquatic, gill-bearing vertebrates that live in water, ranging widely in size and habitat.
animals.Flamingo: A tall wading bird with pink or red plumage, known for its long legs and neck.
animals.Fox: A small to medium-sized carnivorous mammal, known for its bushy tail and cunning behavior.
animals.Frog: An amphibian with a short body, long legs for jumping, and smooth skin, often found near water.
animals.Giraffe: The tallest land animal, known for its long neck and legs, native to African savannas.
animals.Goat: A domesticated ruminant mammal, raised for its milk, meat, and wool, known for its climbing ability.
animals.Gorilla: The largest living primate, a ground-dwelling ape native to Africa, known for its strength and intelligence.
animals.Grizzly: A subspecies of brown bear found in North America, known for its size and hump over the shoulders.
animals.Hedgehog: A small mammal covered with spines, known for curling into a ball for protection.
animals.Hippopotamus: A large, mostly aquatic mammal with a barrel-shaped body, native to African rivers and lakes.
animals.Horse: A domesticated mammal used for riding, racing, and farm work, known for its speed and strength.
animals.Hyena: A carnivorous mammal known for its scavenging habits, strong jaws, and distinctive laugh-like calls.
animals.Jaguar: A large, powerful feline with a spotted coat, native to the Americas and an apex predator in its habitat.
animals.Jellyfish: A free-swimming marine animal with a gelatinous, umbrella-shaped body and tentacles that can sting.
animals.Kangaroo: A marsupial from Australia, known for its powerful hind legs and ability to hop long distances.
animals.Koala: A tree-dwelling marsupial native to Australia, known for its diet of eucalyptus leaves.
animals.Leopard: A large feline with a spotted coat, known for its agility and ability to climb trees.
animals.Lion: A large, social feline known as the 'king of the jungle,' native to Africa and parts of Asia.
animals.Llama: A domesticated South American mammal, used for carrying loads and valued for its wool.
animals.Mandrill: A colorful primate with a distinctive red and blue face, found in Central African rainforests.
animals.Meerkat: A small, social mongoose native to southern Africa, known for its upright stance and cooperative behavior.
animals.Mouse: A small rodent with a pointed snout, rounded ears, and a long tail, common in many habitats.
animals.Orangutan: A great ape native to Indonesia and Malaysia, known for its intelligence and reddish-brown fur.
animals.Otter: A playful aquatic mammal with a streamlined body, often seen floating on its back while eating.
animals.Ox: A domesticated bovine used as a draft animal, known for its strength and endurance.
animals.Panda: A large bear-like mammal with distinctive black and white markings, native to China and a bamboo eater.
animals.Parrot: A colorful, intelligent bird known for its ability to mimic sounds and words.
animals.Penguin: A flightless seabird adapted for swimming, with a black and white coat, found primarily in the Southern Hemisphere.
animals.Rabbit: A small mammal with long ears and a short, fluffy tail, known for its burrowing and quick movements.
animals.Raccoon: A nocturnal mammal with a distinctive black mask-like face and ringed tail, native to the Americas.
animals.Reindeer: A large deer species, also known as caribou, found in Arctic regions and known for its role in folklore.
animals.Rhino: A large, thick-skinned mammal with one or two horns on its snout, found in Africa and Asia.
animals.Seahorse: A small marine fish with a horse-like head and a prehensile tail, known for its upright swimming posture.
animals.Seal: A marine mammal with a streamlined body and flippers, adapted for life in the water.
animals.Shark: A large marine predator with a cartilaginous skeleton, sharp teeth, and excellent senses for hunting.
animals.Sheepdog: A breed of dog trained to herd sheep, known for its intelligence and loyalty.
animals.Snail: A slow-moving mollusk with a coiled shell and a soft, slimy body.
animals.Spider: An arachnid with eight legs and the ability to produce silk, often used to create webs for catching prey.
animals.Squirrel: A small, agile rodent with a bushy tail, known for climbing trees and storing nuts.
animals.Toad: A tailless amphibian with dry, warty skin, often found in damp or wet habitats.
animals.Walrus: A large marine mammal with long tusks and whiskers, found in Arctic regions.
animals.Wasp: An insect with a slender body and a narrow waist, capable of delivering painful stings.
animals.Wolf: A large, wild canine known for its pack behavior and haunting howls.
animals.Yak: A long-haired bovine found in the Himalayas and Central Asia, used for transport and milk production.
animals.Zebra: A hoofed mammal with distinctive black and white stripes, native to the grasslands of Africa.

cars.Audi: A German automobile manufacturer known for its luxury vehicles and innovative engineering.
cars.Bentley: A British manufacturer of luxury cars, renowned for its handcrafted interiors and high-performance vehicles.
cars.BMW: A German company that produces luxury vehicles and motorcycles, known for its sporty and premium designs.
cars.Bugatti: A French luxury car manufacturer famous for its high-performance hypercars, such as the Chiron and Veyron.
cars.Buick: An American automobile brand under General Motors, offering premium vehicles aimed at comfort and style.
cars.Cadillac: A luxury vehicle brand from the United States, recognized for its elegant designs and advanced technology.
cars.Chevrolet: An American car manufacturer producing a wide range of vehicles, from trucks to electric cars.
cars.Chrysler: An American automobile manufacturer known for its mid-range and luxury vehicles.
cars.Citroën: A French car manufacturer known for its innovative designs and economical vehicles.
cars.Corvette: An iconic American sports car produced by Chevrolet, known for its high performance and sleek design.

cars.Daewoo: A South Korean car manufacturer, now defunct, that produced a variety of economical vehicles.
cars.DAF: A Dutch truck manufacturer, primarily producing heavy-duty commercial vehicles.
cars.Daihatsu: A Japanese car manufacturer known for producing small, economical vehicles and kei cars.
cars.Dodge: An American brand of cars and trucks known for its performance vehicles and muscle cars.
cars.Ferrari: An Italian luxury sports car manufacturer, synonymous with speed, style, and motorsport success.
cars.Fiat: An Italian car manufacturer producing small, affordable vehicles and innovative designs.
cars.Ford: An American automaker known for its reliable vehicles and innovations in mass production.
cars.GAZ: A Russian manufacturer of cars, trucks, and buses, known for its utilitarian and durable designs.
cars.GMC: A division of General Motors specializing in trucks, SUVs, and commercial vehicles.

cars.Honda: A Japanese automaker known for its reliable cars, motorcycles, and hybrid vehicles.
cars.Hummer: An American brand known for its rugged, military-inspired SUVs and trucks.
cars.Hyundai: A South Korean automobile manufacturer producing a wide range of vehicles, from economy cars to luxury SUVs.
cars.Infiniti: The luxury vehicle division of Nissan, offering high-performance and technologically advanced cars.
cars.Isuzu: A Japanese manufacturer of commercial vehicles, diesel engines, and SUVs.
cars.Iveco: An Italian company specializing in the production of commercial vehicles, trucks, and buses.
cars.Jaguar: A British luxury car manufacturer known for its stylish, high-performance vehicles.
cars.Jeep: An American brand famous for its rugged, off-road capable SUVs and trucks.
cars.Kia: A South Korean automobile manufacturer offering affordable, reliable, and increasingly innovative vehicles.
cars.Königsegg: A Swedish manufacturer of high-performance hypercars, known for pushing the boundaries of automotive engineering.
cars.Lada: A Russian car manufacturer known for its affordable and durable vehicles, especially in rugged conditions.
cars.Lamborghini: An Italian luxury sports car manufacturer known for its bold designs and high performance.
cars.Lancia: An Italian car manufacturer, part of Fiat Chrysler, known for its stylish and innovative vehicles.
cars.Lexus: The luxury vehicle division of Toyota, renowned for its comfort, reliability, and advanced features.
cars.Lincoln: A luxury car division of Ford, offering premium and elegant vehicles.
cars.Lotus: A British manufacturer of lightweight sports cars and racing vehicles, known for their agility and performance.
cars.Maserati: An Italian luxury car manufacturer, producing high-performance sedans, sports cars, and SUVs.
cars.Maybach: A German luxury brand under Mercedes-Benz, known for its opulent and ultra-luxurious vehicles.
cars.Mazda: A Japanese car manufacturer known for its sporty, reliable cars and innovative engine technologies.
cars.McLaren: A British manufacturer of high-performance sports cars and Formula 1 race cars.
cars.Mercedes-AMG: The performance division of Mercedes-Benz, producing high-powered luxury vehicles.
cars.Mercedes-Benz: A German luxury vehicle manufacturer, known for its high-quality engineering and sophisticated designs.
cars.MG: A British automotive brand known for its affordable sports cars and compact vehicles.
cars.Mini: A British automotive brand owned by BMW, known for its compact and stylish cars.
cars.Mitsubishi: A Japanese automaker producing a range of vehicles, including SUVs, electric cars, and trucks.
cars.Morgan: A British car manufacturer known for its hand-crafted, retro-styled sports cars.
cars.Moskwitsch: A Soviet-era Russian car manufacturer known for producing affordable and practical vehicles.
cars.Nissan: A Japanese car manufacturer producing a wide range of vehicles, from economy cars to electric vehicles like the Leaf.
cars.Oldsmobile: A defunct American car manufacturer, once known for producing reliable mid-range and luxury vehicles.
cars.Opel: A German automobile manufacturer known for producing practical and economical cars.
cars.Pagani: An Italian manufacturer of hypercars, known for its artistic and high-performance designs.
cars.Peugeot: A French car manufacturer producing a wide range of vehicles, from compact cars to commercial vans.
cars.Piaggio: An Italian manufacturer known for its scooters, motorcycles, and compact vehicles.
cars.Plymouth: A defunct American automobile brand known for its affordable and practical vehicles.
cars.Polaris: An American manufacturer of ATVs, snowmobiles, and other recreational vehicles.
cars.Pontiac: A defunct American automobile brand known for its sporty and performance-oriented vehicles.
cars.Porsche: A German manufacturer of high-performance sports cars, SUVs, and sedans.
cars.Renault: A French automaker known for its versatile and economical cars, as well as electric vehicles.
cars.Rover: A defunct British car manufacturer known for its luxury sedans and off-road vehicles.
cars.Saab: A defunct Swedish car manufacturer, known for its innovative and safety-oriented vehicles.

city-country.Ukraine: A European country known for its vast plains and historic cities like Kyiv.
city-country.Uruguay: A South American country known for its beaches and progressive policies.
city-country.Uzbekistan: A Central Asian country with a rich history along the Silk Road.
city-country.Vanuatu: A Pacific island nation known for its volcanoes and traditional culture.
city-country.Yemen: A Middle Eastern country with a rich history and architecture in cities like Sana'a.
city-country.Zambia: A Southern African country known for its Victoria Falls and wildlife.
city-country.Zimbabwe: A Southern African country known for its ancient ruins and Victoria Falls.

food.Applesauce: A sweet or tart sauce made from cooked apples, often used as a side dish or dessert.
food.Beer: An alcoholic beverage made from fermented grains, typically barley, flavored with hops.
food.Bratwurst: A type of German sausage made from pork, beef, or veal, often grilled or pan-fried.
food.Butter: A dairy product made by churning cream, commonly used as a spread or in cooking.
food.Camembert: A soft, creamy, surface-ripened French cheese with a white rind.
food.Chocolate: A sweet food made from roasted and ground cacao beans, often mixed with sugar and milk.
food.Ciabatta: An Italian bread with a chewy texture and a crisp crust, often used for sandwiches.
food.Cola: A carbonated soft drink flavored with caramel and citrus oils, such as Coca-Cola or Pepsi.
food.Cornflakes: A breakfast cereal made from toasted corn, usually served with milk.
food.Cream: A dairy product with a high-fat content, often used in cooking or as a topping.
food.Crispbread: A thin, crisp bread or cracker, often made from rye flour, popular in Scandinavian cuisine.
food.Croissant: A buttery, flaky, crescent-shaped pastry of French origin.
food.Croquettes: Fried breadcrumb-covered food, often filled with mashed potatoes, meat, or vegetables.
food.Currywurst: A German fast-food dish consisting of sausage topped with curry-flavored ketchup.
food.Donut: A fried dough confection, typically ring-shaped, often glazed or dusted with sugar.
food.Duck: A type of poultry known for its rich and flavorful meat, often roasted or braised.
food.Dürüm: A Turkish wrap made with flatbread and filled with meats like kebab, vegetables, and sauces.
food.Eggs: Edible oval-shaped reproductive bodies laid by birds, often used in cooking or baking.
food.Falafel: Deep-fried balls or patties made from ground chickpeas or fava beans, a staple in Middle Eastern cuisine.
food.Frikadelle: A German-style meat patty made from ground meat, breadcrumbs, and spices.
food.Fruit: The edible, seed-bearing structure of flowering plants, often sweet or tart in flavor.
food.Fruitcake: A dense cake made with candied or dried fruits, nuts, and spices, often served during holidays.
food.Goose: A type of poultry with rich, dark meat, often roasted as a festive dish.
food.Gouda: A mild, semi-hard cheese originating from the Netherlands, named after the city of Gouda.
food.Hamburger: A sandwich consisting of a cooked ground meat patty placed between sliced bread or a bun.
food.Honey: A sweet, viscous food substance produced by bees from floral nectar.
food.Jello: A gelatin-based dessert available in various flavors, often served as a wobbly dessert.
food.KFC: Kentucky Fried Chicken, a fast-food chain specializing in fried chicken and sides.
food.Lemonade: A sweetened lemon-flavored beverage, often served cold as a refreshing drink.
food.Licorice: A chewy candy flavored with the root extract of the licorice plant or anise.
food.Liqueur: A sweet, flavored alcoholic beverage, often used in cocktails or as a dessert drink.
food.Mackerel: A type of oily fish, rich in omega-3 fatty acids, often smoked or grilled.
food.Margarine: A butter substitute made from vegetable oils or animal fats, used as a spread or in cooking.
food.Marmalade: A citrus fruit preserve made from the peel and juice of oranges or other citrus fruits.
food.Marzipan: A confection made from ground almonds and sugar, often used for decoration or as a filling.
food.Mascarpone: A rich, creamy Italian cheese, often used in desserts like tiramisu.
food.Mayonnaise: A thick, creamy sauce made from egg yolks, oil, and vinegar or lemon juice.
food.McDonalds: A global fast-food chain known for its burgers, fries, and other quick-service meals.
food.Milk: A white liquid produced by mammals, consumed as a beverage or used in cooking.
food.Mousse: A light, airy dessert made from whipped cream, eggs, and flavors like chocolate or fruit.
food.Mozzarella: A soft, white Italian cheese traditionally made from buffalo milk, commonly used in pizza.
food.Muesli: A breakfast dish made from raw oats, nuts, dried fruits, and often milk or yogurt.
food.Nutella: A popular chocolate and hazelnut spread, often used on bread or in desserts.
food.Nuts: Edible seeds or fruits encased in a hard shell, such as almonds, walnuts, or cashews.
food.Olives: Small fruits of the olive tree, often cured and used in cooking or as snacks.
food.Oranges: Citrus fruits with a sweet, tangy flavor, high in vitamin C.
food.Pancakes: Flat, round cakes made from batter, cooked on a griddle, often served with syrup or fruit.
food.Pasta: A staple Italian food made from durum wheat flour, formed into shapes and cooked in boiling water.
food.Pesto: An Italian sauce made from basil, garlic, pine nuts, Parmesan cheese, and olive oil.
food.Pollock: A type of white fish, often used in fish sticks and other processed seafood products.
food.Popcorn: Puffed kernels of corn, often served as a snack and flavored with salt or butter.
food.Potatoes: Starchy tubers, widely consumed as a staple food, prepared in various ways such as mashed, fried, or roasted.
food.Pudding: A creamy dessert, often made from milk, sugar, and flavorings, thickened with starch or eggs.
food.Rice: A staple grain widely consumed around the world, often boiled or steamed.
food.Rollmops: Pickled herring fillets rolled around a piece of onion or pickle, a traditional German dish.
food.Rolls: Small, round pieces of bread, often served as a side dish.
food.Salami: A cured sausage made from fermented and air-dried meat, typically pork or beef.
food.Salmon: A type of oily fish, rich in omega-3 fatty acids, often grilled, smoked, or raw in sushi.
food.Saltines: Thin, crisp crackers lightly salted on the surface, often served as a snack or with soup.
food.Shrimp: Small crustaceans often used in seafood dishes, known for their delicate, sweet flavor.
food.Soup: A liquid dish made by simmering ingredients like vegetables, meat, or fish in broth.
food.Speisequark: A German dairy product similar to soft cheese or thick yogurt, often used in cooking or desserts.
food.Spätzle: A type of soft egg noodle from Germany, often served as a side dish with gravy or cheese.
food.Starbucks: A global coffeehouse chain known for its specialty coffee drinks and snacks.
food.Steak: A slice of high-quality meat, often beef, cooked by grilling, frying, or broiling.
food.Subway: A global fast-food chain specializing in made-to-order submarine sandwiches.
food.Sushi: A Japanese dish consisting of vinegared rice, often topped or rolled with seafood or vegetables.
food.Tiramisu: An Italian dessert made with layers of coffee-soaked ladyfingers, mascarpone, and cocoa.
food.Toast: Sliced bread browned by exposure to heat, often served with butter or toppings.
food.Trout: A freshwater fish, often grilled or pan-fried, known for its mild flavor.
food.Vegetables: Edible plants or parts of plants, such as carrots, spinach, or broccoli, rich in nutrients.
food.Whiskey: A distilled alcoholic beverage made from fermented grain mash, aged in wooden casks.
food.Wiener: A type of sausage originating in Vienna, Austria, often called a hot dog in the U.S.
food.Wine: An alcoholic beverage made from fermented grapes or other fruits.
food.Yogurt: A fermented dairy product made by adding bacteria to milk, often consumed plain or with fruit.

literature.1984: A dystopian novel by George Orwell, depicting a totalitarian regime under constant surveillance.
literature.Blindness: A novel by José Saramago about a city struck by an epidemic of blindness, exploring human nature and society.
literature.Demons: A novel by Fyodor Dostoevsky, dealing with political and philosophical themes in 19th-century Russia.
literature.Ficciones: A collection of short stories by Jorge Luis Borges, exploring themes of infinity, identity, and reality.
literature.Hamlet: A tragedy by William Shakespeare, about Prince Hamlet's quest for revenge against his uncle, who has usurped the throne.
literature.Hunger: A novel by Knut Hamsun, depicting the struggles of a starving writer in a European city.
literature.Lolita: A controversial novel by Vladimir Nabokov, exploring the relationship between a middle-aged man and a young girl.
literature.Mahabharata: An ancient Indian epic, recounting the Kurukshetra War and the moral dilemmas faced by its characters.
literature.Medea: A tragedy by Euripides, centered on the vengeance of Medea against her unfaithful husband, Jason.
literature.Metamorphoses: A narrative poem by Ovid, chronicling mythological transformations in Roman and Greek mythology.
literature.Middlemarch: A novel by George Eliot, exploring the lives and relationships in a fictional English town.
literature.Nostromo: A novel by Joseph Conrad, addressing issues of imperialism, corruption, and human greed in a fictional South American country.
literature.Othello: A tragedy by William Shakespeare, telling the story of Othello, a Moorish general, and his descent into jealousy and betrayal.
literature.Ramayana: An ancient Indian epic, narrating the story of Prince Rama, his wife Sita, and their trials and adventures.
literature.Ulysses: A modernist novel by James Joyce, chronicling a day in the life of Leopold Bloom in Dublin.
literature.The Iliad: An ancient Greek epic poem attributed to Homer, recounting the events of the Trojan War.
literature.Pride and Prejudice: A novel by Jane Austen, exploring themes of love, social status, and personal growth in Regency-era England.
literature.Moby-Dick: A novel by Herman Melville, about a captain's obsessive quest to hunt a giant white whale.
literature.Crime and Punishment: A novel by Fyodor Dostoevsky, focusing on a young man's psychological turmoil after committing a murder.
literature.The Great Gatsby: A novel by F. Scott Fitzgerald, exploring themes of wealth, love, and the American Dream in the Jazz Age.

people.Bono: An Irish singer and activist, best known as the lead vocalist of the band U2.
people.Eminem: An American rapper and songwriter, known for his controversial lyrics and influence on hip-hop.
people.Michelangelo: An Italian Renaissance artist and sculptor, famous for works like the Sistine Chapel ceiling and David.
people.Rembrandt: A Dutch painter and etcher, celebrated for his portraits and mastery of light and shadow.
people.Leonardo da Vinci: An Italian polymath of the Renaissance, known for masterpieces like the Mona Lisa and The Last Supper.
people.Frida Kahlo: A Mexican painter known for her vibrant and surreal self-portraits.
people.Albert Einstein: A theoretical physicist who developed the theory of relativity and contributed significantly to modern science.
people.Marie Curie: A physicist and chemist, the first woman to win a Nobel Prize and known for her work on radioactivity.
people.William Shakespeare: An English playwright and poet, widely regarded as one of the greatest writers in the English language.
people.Beethoven: A German composer and pianist, known for his symphonies and influential contributions to classical music.

sports.Aikido: A Japanese martial art focusing on harmony and redirecting an opponent's energy.
sports.Airsoft: A sport in which players use replica guns to shoot non-metallic pellets in simulated combat.
sports.Aquaball: A water-based team sport involving a ball, similar to water polo.
sports.Archery: A sport where competitors use a bow to shoot arrows at a target for accuracy.
sports.Athletics: A collection of competitive sports including running, jumping, throwing, and walking.
sports.Autoball: A sport combining elements of soccer and car driving, often involving vehicles hitting a large ball.
sports.Backgammon: A board game of strategy and chance, played with dice and checkers.
sports.Badminton: A racket sport where players hit a shuttlecock over a net to score points.
sports.Ballooning: A sport or leisure activity involving flying in hot air balloons.
sports.Baseball: A team sport where players hit a ball and run bases to score runs.
sports.Basketball: A team sport where players aim to score points by shooting a ball through a hoop.
sports.Beachminton: A variation of badminton played on a beach with modified rules.
sports.Beachrugby: A form of rugby played on a beach, often with fewer players and simplified rules.
sports.Biathlon: A winter sport combining cross-country skiing and rifle shooting.
sports.Billiards: A cue sport played on a table, aiming to pocket balls in designated pockets.
sports.Bobsleigh: A winter sport where teams race down an ice track in a sled.
sports.Boccia: A precision ball sport similar to bocce, designed for athletes with disabilities.
sports.Bodybuilding: A sport focused on developing muscle mass and symmetry through weight training and diet.
sports.Bouldering: A form of rock climbing performed on small rock formations or artificial walls without ropes.
sports.Bowling: A sport where players roll a ball to knock down pins arranged in a triangular pattern.
sports.Boxing: A combat sport where two participants throw punches at each other while wearing gloves.
sports.Breakdance: A style of street dance that combines acrobatics and rhythmic moves, often competitive.
sports.Bridge: A strategic card game played by four players in two partnerships.
sports.Bullfighting: A traditional spectacle in which a matador faces a bull in a bullring.
sports.Canyoning: An adventure sport involving navigating canyons through climbing, swimming, and rappelling.
sports.Capoeira: A Brazilian martial art that combines elements of dance, acrobatics, and music.
sports.Carambolage: A form of billiards played on a table without pockets.
sports.Checkers: A board game where players move pieces diagonally to capture the opponent's pieces.
sports.Cheerleading: A sport combining acrobatics, dance, and cheering to motivate teams or entertain audiences.
sports.Chess: A strategic board game played between two players, focusing on checkmating the opponent's king.
sports.Climbing: An activity or sport where participants ascend natural rock formations or artificial walls.
sports.Cockfighting: A traditional blood sport where roosters fight each other, often controversial.
sports.Cricket: A bat-and-ball team sport played on a field, with runs scored by hitting the ball.
sports.CrossFit: A fitness regimen combining elements of high-intensity interval training and strength exercises.
sports.Crossgolf: A variation of golf played in urban or unconventional areas.
sports.Curling: A winter sport where players slide stones on ice towards a target, aiming for accuracy.
sports.Darts: A game where players throw small, pointed darts at a circular target to score points.
sports.Diving: A water sport where participants perform acrobatics while jumping into a pool.
sports.Dodgeball: A team sport where players aim to eliminate opponents by hitting them with a ball.
sports.Fencing: A combat sport where competitors score points by striking their opponent with a weapon.
sports.Finger-wrestling: A traditional game where two participants lock fingers and try to pin the opponent's hand.
sports.Fishing: The act of catching fish for sport, leisure, or food using rods, nets, or traps.
sports.Flamenco: A Spanish dance form combining percussive footwork, guitar, and singing, often performed competitively.
sports.Geocaching: An outdoor recreational activity where participants use GPS to hide and seek containers.
sports.Gliding: A sport where participants fly unpowered aircraft, relying on air currents for movement.
sports.Golf: A sport where players use clubs to hit a ball into a series of holes in as few strokes as possible.
sports.Gymnastics: A sport involving physical exercises and routines showcasing strength, flexibility, and coordination.
sports.Handball: A team sport where players use their hands to pass a ball and score in the opponent's goal.
sports.Hiking: A leisure activity involving walking on trails or paths in natural environments.
sports.Hurdles: A track and field event where athletes jump over obstacles while running.
sports.Judo: A Japanese martial art focusing on throws and grappling techniques.
sports.Karate: A Japanese martial art emphasizing striking techniques using punches, kicks, and blocks.
sports.Karting: A motor sport involving racing small, open-wheel vehicles on dedicated tracks.
sports.Kickboxing: A combat sport combining elements of boxing with kicking techniques.
sports.Kitesurfing: A water sport where participants use a kite to harness wind power while surfing on water.
sports.Mill: A traditional board game also known as Nine Men's Morris, involving strategic placement and movement of pieces.
sports.Mountaineering: A sport or activity involving climbing mountains, often requiring technical skills and equipment.
sports.Paintball: A game where players eliminate opponents by shooting them with dye-filled pellets.
sports.Parkour: A physical discipline where participants move through environments using efficient movements like jumping and climbing.
sports.Pilates: A fitness system focusing on core strength, flexibility, and controlled movements.
sports.Poker: A card game involving strategy, skill, and betting, often played competitively.
sports.Polo: A team sport played on horseback where players use mallets to hit a ball into the opposing team's goal.
sports.Pool: A cue sport played on a table with pockets, using a cue stick to hit balls.
sports.Rafting: An outdoor activity involving navigating rivers in an inflatable raft, often through rapids.
sports.Rally: A motorsport involving timed stages on closed public roads or off-road tracks.
sports.Rodeo: A competitive sport involving horseback riding and cattle handling, such as bull riding or roping.
sports.Rowing: A water sport where participants use oars to propel a boat in races or recreational activities.
sports.Rugby: A contact team sport where players aim to carry, pass, or kick a ball to score points.
sports.Sailing: A sport or leisure activity involving navigating a boat using wind power.
sports.Scrabble: A word game where players use letter tiles to form words on a board and score points.
sports.Shuffleboard: A game where players slide pucks along a smooth surface towards a target area to score points.
sports.Skat: A German card game for three players, involving strategy and skill.
sports.Skateboarding: A sport where participants ride on a board with wheels, performing tricks and stunts.
sports.Skittles: A traditional bowling game played with nine pins.
sports.Skydiving: A sport where participants jump from an aircraft and freefall before deploying a parachute.
sports.Snooker: A cue sport played on a large table, involving potting balls in a specific sequence.
sports.Snowboard: A winter sport where participants slide down snow-covered slopes on a board.
sports.Soccer: A team sport where players aim to score by kicking a ball into the opponent's goal.
sports.Squash: A racket sport played by hitting a ball against a wall within a court.
sports.Steeplechase: A distance-running race with obstacles such as barriers and water jumps.
sports.Streetball: An informal variation of basketball, often played outdoors with modified rules.
sports.Sudoku: A puzzle game where players fill a 9x9 grid with numbers following specific rules.
sports.Swimming: A water sport or activity where participants move through water using various strokes.
sports.Taekwondo: A Korean martial art emphasizing high kicks and quick strikes.
sports.Tennis: A racket sport where players hit a ball over a net to score points.
sports.Tipp-Kick: A table football game where players control figures to kick a ball.
sports.Trekking: A long, adventurous journey on foot, often in remote or mountainous areas.
sports.Triathlon: A multi-sport event combining swimming, cycling, and running.
sports.Volleyball: A team sport where players hit a ball over a net, aiming to score on the opponent's court.
sports.Wakeboarding: A water sport where participants ride a board while being towed by a boat.
sports.Weightlifting: A strength sport where athletes lift weights in specific techniques, such as snatch and clean-and-jerk.
sports.Windsurfing: A water sport combining surfing and sailing using a board with an attached sail.
sports.Wrestling: A combat sport involving grappling techniques to pin or submit an opponent.
sports.Yoga: A physical and mental discipline originating from India, focusing on postures, breathing, and meditation.

things.Airship: A powered aircraft lighter than air, often used for transport or advertising.
things.Antenna: A device used to transmit or receive electromagnetic waves, such as for radio or television.
things.Atomizer: A device that converts liquid into a fine spray, often used in perfumes or medical sprays.
things.Backpack: A bag with shoulder straps, carried on the back and used for carrying belongings.
things.Bedding: Materials such as sheets and blankets used to make a bed comfortable for sleeping.
things.BluRay: An optical disc format used for storing high-definition video and data.
things.Bowl: A round, deep dish used for holding food or liquids.
things.Broom: A cleaning tool with bristles used to sweep floors.
things.Cable: A thick, strong rope or a set of wires used to transmit electricity or signals.
things.Carpet: A floor covering made from woven fabric, often used for decoration and comfort.
things.CD: A compact disc used to store digital data, such as music or software.
things.Centrifuge: A machine that uses centrifugal force to separate substances of different densities.
things.Chopsticks: A pair of slender sticks used as eating utensils in many East Asian cultures.
things.Clothesline: A cord or wire used for hanging clothes to dry.
things.Clothespin: A small device used to fasten clothes to a line for drying.
things.Colander: A kitchen utensil with holes used for draining liquid from food such as pasta.
things.Computer: An electronic device for processing, storing, and retrieving data and performing computations.
things.Corkscrew: A tool for extracting corks from bottles, especially wine bottles.
things.Cutlery: Utensils used for eating or serving food, such as knives, forks, and spoons.
things.Dishes: Plates, bowls, and other utensils used for serving and eating food.
things.Dishwasher: An appliance for automatically cleaning dishes, glasses, and utensils.
things.Duster: A cleaning tool used to remove dust from surfaces.
things.Dustpan: A flat container with a handle used to collect dust swept with a broom.
things.DVD: A digital versatile disc used for storing video, audio, or data.
things.Dynamo: A device that generates electricity, often used in bicycles or older power systems.
things.Fan: A device with rotating blades used to create airflow for cooling or ventilation.
things.Flag: A piece of cloth with a specific design, used as a symbol for a country or organization.
things.Flashlight: A portable handheld device that emits light from a bulb or LED.
things.Freezer: An appliance used for freezing and storing food at low temperatures.
things.Hammer: A tool with a heavy head used for pounding nails or breaking objects.
things.Helicopter: An aircraft with rotating blades that allow it to take off and land vertically.
things.Hovercraft: A vehicle that floats above the ground or water on a cushion of air.
things.Humidifier: A device that adds moisture to the air to improve humidity levels.
things.Iron: An appliance used to press and remove wrinkles from clothes and fabrics.
things.Kettle: A container used for boiling water, often with a spout and handle.
things.Keyboard: A set of keys used for typing on computers or musical instruments.
things.Ladder: A structure with steps or rungs used for climbing to higher areas.
things.Massager: A device used to relieve muscle tension and promote relaxation through vibration or pressure.
things.Monitor: A screen used to display visual information from a computer or other device.
things.Mop: A cleaning tool with a long handle and absorbent head used to clean floors.
things.Pacemaker: A medical device implanted to regulate heartbeats.
things.Padlock: A portable lock with a shackle, used to secure items such as gates or lockers.
things.Phone: A device used for voice communication, now often incorporating text, video, and internet functions.
things.Pillow: A soft cushion used for supporting the head during sleep.
things.Plunger: A tool used to clear blockages in drains or toilets.
things.Pot: A container used for cooking or storing food, typically made of metal or ceramic.
things.Railroad: A system of tracks on which trains travel for transporting goods or passengers.
things.Refrigerator: An appliance used to keep food and drinks cool and fresh.
things.Satellite: An object placed in orbit around a planet, often used for communication or observation.
things.Scrubber: A tool or device used for cleaning surfaces by scrubbing.
things.Smartphone: A mobile phone with advanced computing capabilities and internet access.
things.Streetcar: A rail vehicle that runs on city streets, used for public transportation.
things.Sunbed: A device that emits ultraviolet light, used for tanning skin artificially.
things.Tablecloth: A covering placed over a table for decoration or protection.
things.Tank: An armored combat vehicle or a large container for storing liquids or gases.
things.Telegraph: An old communication device that transmits messages over wires using electrical signals.
things.Toaster: An appliance used to brown bread by exposing it to heat.
things.Touchpad: A flat surface used to control a cursor on electronic devices, such as laptops.
things.Transistor: A semiconductor device used to amplify or switch electronic signals.
things.Tray: A flat, shallow container used for carrying or serving food and drinks.
things.TV: A device for viewing video content, such as shows and movies.
things.Typewriter: A mechanical device used for typing characters onto paper.
things.Wardrobe: A piece of furniture for storing clothes, or a person's collection of clothing.
things.Waterbed: A bed with a mattress filled with water, often used for therapeutic purposes.
things.Whisk: A kitchen tool with loops used for mixing or whipping ingredients.

tv.Alien: A 1979 sci-fi horror film about a spaceship crew encountering a deadly alien lifeform.
tv.Amélie: A French romantic comedy about a whimsical young woman finding joy in helping others.
tv.Braveheart: A historical epic about William Wallace's fight for Scottish independence.
tv.Casablanca: A classic romantic drama set during World War II, known for its iconic quotes.
tv.Casino: A crime drama about the rise and fall of a Las Vegas casino manager.
tv.Deadpool: A comedic superhero film about a wisecracking anti-hero seeking revenge.
tv.Downfall: A German film depicting Adolf Hitler's final days in his Berlin bunker.
tv.Gladiator: A historical epic about a Roman general seeking revenge after being betrayed.
tv.Goodfellas: A crime film chronicling the rise and fall of a mafia associate.
tv.Inception: A sci-fi thriller about a team of thieves infiltrating dreams to plant an idea.
tv.Interstellar: A sci-fi film about a group of astronauts traveling through a wormhole to save humanity.
tv.Jaws: A thriller about a giant shark terrorizing a small beach town.
tv.Memento: A psychological thriller about a man with short-term memory loss seeking his wife's killer.
tv.Platoon: A war drama depicting the experiences of a young soldier in the Vietnam War.
tv.Psycho: A horror-thriller about a mysterious motel owner and his dark secrets.
tv.Rocky: A sports drama about an underdog boxer striving for success.
tv.Scarface: A crime film about a Cuban immigrant's rise and fall in the drug trade.
tv.Se7en: A psychological thriller about detectives hunting a killer who uses the seven deadly sins as motives.
tv.Shining: A horror film about a man descending into madness while caretaking a haunted hotel.
tv.Up: An animated adventure about an elderly man and a young boy traveling in a flying house.
tv.WALL·E: An animated sci-fi film about a lonely robot cleaning up a trash-filled Earth.
tv.Zootopia: An animated comedy about a rabbit police officer solving a mystery in a city of anthropomorphic animals.

web.Amazon: An online retail giant offering a wide range of products and services.
web.Avatar: A digital representation of a user in online platforms, games, or virtual environments.
web.Bitcoin: A decentralized digital currency based on blockchain technology.
web.Blockchain: A digital ledger technology used for secure and transparent transactions.
web.Blog: An online journal or informational website featuring posts on various topics.
web.Browser: Software used to access and navigate the internet.
web.Cloud: A network of remote servers used to store, manage, and process data.
web.Coinbase: A cryptocurrency exchange platform for buying, selling, and storing digital currencies.
web.Download: The process of transferring data from a server to a local device.
web.eBay: An online marketplace for buying and selling goods through auctions or direct sales.
web.eBook: A digital version of a book, readable on electronic devices.
web.Emoticon: A text-based representation of a facial expression, used in digital communication.
web.Facebook: A social media platform for connecting and sharing with others online.
web.Google: A search engine and tech company offering various online services and products.
web.Hacker: A person skilled in computer programming, often associated with unauthorized access to systems.
web.Hype: Excessive or exaggerated promotion of a product, event, or idea.
web.Influencer: A person with the ability to affect purchasing decisions through social media.
web.Instagram: A social media platform focused on sharing photos and videos.
web.Junk: Unwanted or spam emails or content found online.
web.Login: The process of gaining access to a system by entering credentials.
web.Logout: The process of exiting a system to terminate access.
web.Malware: Malicious software designed to damage or disrupt computer systems.
web.Mention: Referring to someone in a post or message on social media platforms.
web.Nerd: A term for someone deeply interested in technical or niche subjects, often in computing or science.
web.Netflix: A streaming service offering movies, TV shows, and original programming.
web.Newsletter: A digital or print publication distributed regularly to subscribers.
web.Password: A secret code used for securing access to accounts or systems.
web.PayPal: An online payment platform for secure transactions and money transfers.
web.Pinterest: A visual discovery platform for sharing and exploring creative ideas.
web.Privacy: The right or ability to control personal information shared online.
web.Reddit: A social news aggregation and discussion platform with communities based on interests.
web.Signal: A messaging app focused on privacy and secure communication.
web.Snapchat: A social media app for sharing temporary photos and videos.
web.Spam: Unsolicited messages, often sent in bulk for advertising purposes.
web.Spotify: A music streaming service offering a vast library of songs and podcasts.
web.Telegram: A cloud-based messaging app known for its speed and security features.
web.Tidal: A music streaming service offering high-quality audio and exclusive content.
web.Tinder: A dating app where users swipe to like or dislike profiles.
web.Tweet: A post made on the social media platform Twitter.
web.Twitch: A live streaming platform popular for video gaming and esports content.
web.Twitter: A social media platform for sharing short posts called tweets.
web.Update: A new version of software or information to improve functionality or security.
web.Viral: Content that spreads rapidly online through shares and engagement.
web.Virus: Malicious software or code designed to damage or disrupt systems.
web.VPN: Virtual Private Network, a service for secure and private internet browsing.
web.Webcam: A camera used for video recording or live streaming via the internet.
web.WhatsApp: A messaging app allowing users to send texts, voice, and video calls.
web.Wikipedia: An online encyclopedia offering free, crowd-sourced information on various topics.
web.YouTube: A video-sharing platform where users can upload, view, and comment on videos.
